image.altText: Kathleen Folbigg broke down whilst giving evidence in court in 2019

items.synopsis: NSW Attorney-General Michael Daley says Kathleen Folbigg has been pardoned — she's spent two decades behind bars after being found guilty of killing her four children.

title.children: Kathleen Folbigg pardoned after spending 20 years in jail over killing her four children

image.altText: A composite image with sepia tones of a woman's face, and four baby photographs.

items.synopsis: Kathleen Folbigg was no stranger to tragedy when all of her children died before their second birthdays. This is how someone once known as Australia's worst female serial killer was freed from prison.

title.children: Long road to freedom: Kathleen Folbigg's tragic life started well before her babies died

image.altText: Close-up of man

items.synopsis: Justice Anthony Besanko has released his full judgement after dismissing Ben Roberts-Smith's defamation suit on Thursday. Follow live

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith full defamation judgement revealed

image.altText: Palaszczuk holds report and looks down.

items.synopsis: Governments never fare well in by-elections, but is there anything to be gained in Fadden for a Queensland government on the back foot?

title.children: How Queensland Labor might frame an almost-certain federal loss as a success

image.altText: A Woolworths sign next to a Coles sign outside the shops

items.synopsis: The Fair Work Ombudsman tells the Federal Court that Coles and Woolworths have to pay for allegedly ripping off store workers via an illicit salary system.

title.children: Woolworths and Coles accused of setting up 'foreign' pay system to rip off workers

image.altText: a police car in front of a road

items.synopsis: The fatality comes after a pre-dawn crash involving animals that appear to have escaped from a camel farm near Rockhampton.

title.children: School bus driver dies after collision with two camels in central Queensland

image.altText: A close-up of brown Aspen Methadone Syrup bottles

items.synopsis: More than a dozen private opioid treatment services in Queensland and New South Wales are at risk of closure because of changes announced in last month's federal budget, say clinic operators.

title.children: Warning of 'imminent disaster' as government changes may leave people addicted to opioids with nowhere to turn

image.altText: An illustration of Islamic State iconography superimposed over a browser window containing an image of Rick Astley.

items.synopsis: Defeating Islamic State militants required disabling their significant cyber capabilities — and pop star Rick Astley unwittingly played a hand in doing so.

title.children: In the heat of battle, IS militants' phones were hijacked thanks to Australians inspired by Rick Astley

image.altText: A man of colour in a blue suit and white shirt stands and points at a computer screen where a young Asian woman is working.

items.synopsis: With productivity falling in Australia and AI developments advancing, could the technology be the answer to boosting output, or will it cause more job losses?

title.children: Amit's firm has modelled the jobs most likely to be affected by AI. The top 10 might surprise you

image.altText: An aerial shot of a large refugee camp.

items.synopsis: A group of 26 Australians living in a camp in Syria have launched legal action against the Department of Home Affairs. Lawyers for the women and children say they were tricked into going to the conflict zone.

title.children: Families take legal action to compel the government to repatriate them from Syrian camp

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann speaks to 7NEWS Spotlight in an interview.

items.synopsis: Former Liberal staffer Bruce Lehrmann says he may still sue Brittany Higgins personally for defamation, in his first television interview since she accused him of raping her at Parliament House in 2019.

title.children: '50pc of the country thinks I'm a rapist': Bruce Lehrmann says he may sue Brittany Higgins over allegation he denies

image.altText: Humpback whale with swollen tongue

items.synopsis: Authorities have closed a beach on the NSW Mid North Coast as they work to remove the body of a 15-tonne whale.

title.children: Whale carcass washes up on popular regional NSW beach

image.altText: A close shot of Bandt's face, looking serious and wearing glasses.

items.synopsis: The Australian Greens adopts a new party position on Palestine and Israel, saying Israel is practising the "crime of apartheid".

title.children: Greens call for boycott of far-right Israeli leaders

image.altText: A Qantas jet passes a Jetstar plane, the logos on their tails visible.

items.synopsis: The federal government should consider forcing airlines to pay passengers compensation if their flights get cancelled or delayed, a new consumer watchdog report says.

title.children: Qantas-Virgin duopoly to blame for high fares and poor customer service: ACCC

image.altText: A close up of Harry walking with a neutral expression.

items.synopsis: This week, Prince Harry is set to testify in the first of his five pending legal cases centred around battles with the British tabloids, in what's being labelled "the royal court case of the century".

title.children: Prince Harry is heading where no royals have gone in a century – a witness box

image.altText: US Air Force F-16 fighter jets in the sky.

items.synopsis: US fighter jets cause a sonic boom across the US capital while scrambling to reach an unresponsive aircraft that ultimately crashed in the mountains of Virginia.

title.children: Sonic boom heard in Washington DC as fighter jets chase 'unresponsive' private plane

image.altText: A woman dribbles during a basketball game

items.synopsis: Opal's representative Tiana Mangakahia has announced her immediate retirement from playing basketball due to an ongoing battle with breast cancer.

title.children: Sydney Flames guard Tiana Mangakahia retires due to ongoing battle with breast cancer

image.altText: An image of the roundabout at Moorooka

items.synopsis: Amid concerns from the community about works on Brisbane's south side where a roundabout has been removed, city council says it will provide an update to residents as soon as possible.

title.children: 'We have listened': Council orders review of Moorooka intersection upgrade

image.altText: A pictures of members of the Russian Volunteer Corps wearing military uniforms and holding rifles.

items.synopsis: The governor of Russia's Belgorod region has confirmed that fighting was ongoing on his side of the Ukraine border, with pro-Ukrainian forces having taken Russians prisoner during the clashes.

title.children: Pro-Ukrainian forces offer to hand over Russian prisoners in new cross-border clashes

image.altText: A pair of hands prepares to tear up a piece of paper labelled "reward for experience".

items.synopsis: Some of Australia's largest employers and small business owners have united to rally against proposed laws that would require labour hire workers doing the same job at the same site to be paid the same as directly employed workers.

title.children: Business groups mount campaign against 'same job, same pay' workplace reforms

image.altText: A smiling teenager wearing a backwards cap and a pink singlet petting wildlife.

items.synopsis: The homicide investigation into the suspected murder of Linden Malayta, an Indigenous teenager missing for more than four years, has progressed with detectives alleging he was shot.

title.children: Queensland Police allege missing Indigenous teen Linden Malayta was shot

image.altText: A person's blurred shoulder as they walk past a PWC logo.

items.synopsis: Consulting giant PwC is embroiled in a scandal of its own doing, having used confidential government information to benefit its bottom line. Here's how it happened, and what consequences the firm is facing.

title.children: At least 53 people knew about the PwC tax leak — so why don't we know who they are?

image.altText: An ad for an Adelaide nightclub featuring a fake polar bear in a bra.

items.synopsis: An Adelaide nightclub has apologised for a social media campaign, condemned as "misogynistic", in which a free drinks offer was extended to patrons based on their breast sizes.

title.children: Bar that encouraged women to take off bras for free drinks apologises

image.altText: Sheep in pens on live export ship

items.synopsis: The ABC joins a two-week journey aboard a live export sheep carrier from Australia to the Middle East to observe what happens on a typical journey.

title.children: What's life really like for sheep on a live export ship?

image.altText: An emotional Zlatan Ibrahimović makes a heart signal with his hands to fans in Milan as he retires from football.

items.synopsis: Larger-than-life Swedish superstar Zlatan Ibrahimović announces his retirement from football after 24 years at the age of 41 — and countless amazing goals — as a pro, prompting an outpouring of emotion from AC Milan fans, and from the man himself.

title.children: Swedish superstar Zlatan Ibrahimović ends incredible football career with emotional ceremony in Milan

image.altText: Three children, a mother and a child walking together

items.synopsis: Everyone on Jessica's side of her family has been diagnosed with Huntington's disease. She is watching her mother slowly die, and has the condition herself.

title.children: 'I'm watching her die slowly': What it's like having the rare genetic condition Huntington's disease

image.altText: Orange e-scooter left parked on pathway with pedestrians walking in the background at South Brisbane.

items.synopsis: Following new rules introduced by the Queensland government in November, personal mobility device riders have been fined for a range of offences including speeding more than 30kph over the limit.

title.children: E-scooter riders hit with nearly 1,000 fines in first three months of new laws

image.altText: Jamie and Mick at a table, both have one hand on braille protoype, both smiling.

items.synopsis: Mick and Jamie have been mates for almost three decades and have worked on a project with one goal in mind — to ensure everyone can use a computer.

title.children: Mick and Jamie created software that could have made them rich. This is why they don't want a cent

image.altText: A cat lying on its back with its legs in the air on the front seat of a car.

items.synopsis: Bandit might just be the coolest cat in town, attending festivals and frequenting shops and cafes. But to her owner Anthorr, Bandit is much more than an adventure buddy, she's his support to leave the house each day.

title.children: Assistance cat Bandit goes just about everywhere with her owner Anthorr, helping him to deal with PTSD

image.altText: An aerial view of coal extracted from the Narrabri mine, with a landscape of lakes and mountains behind it.

items.synopsis: An ABC analysis uncovers several examples of project approval being granted to coalmines based on environmental assessments that contained significant underestimates of their greenhouse gas pollution.

title.children: This coalmine is polluting three times as much as expected. And that's not unusual

image.altText: a huge crocodile in a small pond

items.synopsis: The giant animal's birthday will be celebrated at its home on Green Island in the Great Barrier Reef.

title.children: Cassius is the largest saltwater crocodile in captivity in the world. He might also be one of the oldest on Earth

image.altText: Miyu Kato

items.synopsis: A doubles pair is sent packing from the French Open after a controversial disqualification, while Novak Djokovic breaks a Rafael Nadal record.

title.children: 'Crying for like 15 minutes': Doubles duo bounced from French Open after ball kid hit

image.altText: An ibis bird perches next to the Reserve Bank of Australia headquarters in central Sydney, Australia February 6, 2018.

items.synopsis: Markets are forecasting the RBA will lift interest rates again at its meeting tomorrow, while the ASX has posted early gains after a debt ceiling crisis in the US was avoided. Follow live.

title.children: Markets predict another interest rate rise, Myer CEO to retire, ASX rallies after US debt deal secured

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Federal Court has heard that Coles and Woolworths short-changed workers on overtime by setting up a payment structure that was foreign to Australia's industrial awards system. The supermarket giants are in court after joint trial was brought by the Fair Work Ombudsman and two class action claimants, alleging that workers have been underpaid for a number of years. In his opening address, Fair Work Ombudsman barrister Justin Bourke KC argued the "entirely foreign" payment structure covering some workers would always "end badly for Woolworths and Coles and its employees". He took Justice Nye Perram to the relevant award, arguing work hours were set at a total of 38 rostered hours per week, before contending that was not what happened in reality. In an "extreme" example, Mr Bourke said one team manager in Sydney was working 13 hours a day. Other workers were doing average shifts of nearly 11 hours, he said. He said evidence would show clear standards had to be met by the companies, and that there was tacit approval of the alleged illegal conduct, submitting they knew people were working above rostered hours "day in day out". There were failures on the use of "informal" rosters, time off in lieu, and record keeping on worker overtime, penalties and allowances, he said. "No one blew a whistle," Mr Bourke said. "They knew it was going on and they have to pay for it." The trial is expected to run for seven weeks.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Coles and Woolworths accused of setting up 'foreign' pay system to rip off workers

children.content: The Federal Court has heard that Coles and Woolworths short-changed workers on overtime by setting up a payment structure that was foreign to Australia's industrial awards system.
The supermarket giants are in court after joint trial was brought by the Fair Work Ombudsman and two class action claimants, alleging that workers have been underpaid for a number of years.

In his opening address, Fair Work Ombudsman barrister Justin Bourke KC argued the "entirely foreign" payment structure covering some workers would always "end badly for Woolworths and Coles and its employees".
He took Justice Nye Perram to the relevant award, arguing work hours were set at a total of 38 rostered hours per week, before contending that was not what happened in reality.
In an "extreme" example, Mr Bourke said one team manager in Sydney was working 13 hours a day.
Other workers were doing average shifts of nearly 11 hours, he said.

He said evidence would show clear standards had to be met by the companies, and that there was tacit approval of the alleged illegal conduct, submitting they knew people were working above rostered hours "day in day out".
There were failures on the use of "informal" rosters, time off in lieu, and record keeping on worker overtime, penalties and allowances, he said.
"No one blew a whistle," Mr Bourke said.
"They knew it was going on and they have to pay for it."
The trial is expected to run for seven weeks.

props.alt: A composite image of Woolworths and Coles supermarkets.

children.content: (ABC News)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: AGL Energy Limited has been served with class action proceedings relating to part of its National Energy Market (NEM) operations. The proceedings allege breaches of the Competition and Consumer Act in relation to bidding in the South Australian region of the NEM. The NEM covers Australia's eastern and south-eastern states, with five physically connected regions — Queensland, New South Wales (which includes the ACT), Victoria, Tasmania and South Australia. In an announcement to the ASX, AGL said it took its "compliance obligations seriously and intends to vigorously defend the proceedings". The class action comes in the wake of broader discussion about the energy market, with prices going up significantly, and an unprecedented federal government-backed intervention in the market last year. You can keep reading this story from Jessica Warriner below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Class action launched against AGL over alleged competition law breaches

featuredLink.title: AGL Energy to 'vigorously defend' class action over alleged competition law breaches

children.content: AGL Energy Limited has been served with class action proceedings relating to part of its National Energy Market (NEM)
operations.
The proceedings allege breaches of the Competition and Consumer Act in relation to bidding in the South Australian region of the NEM.
The NEM covers Australia's eastern and south-eastern states, with five physically connected regions — Queensland, New South Wales (which includes the ACT), Victoria, Tasmania and South Australia.
In an announcement to the ASX, AGL said it took
its "compliance obligations seriously and intends to vigorously defend the proceedings".
The class action comes in the wake of broader discussion about the energy market, with
prices going up significantly, and an unprecedented federal government-backed intervention in the market last year

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Analysts at J.P. Morgan have given their judgement on our local economy and it's an 'as we expected'. Essentially, data from businesses supports what the bank thought would happen in the first quarter of this year. "Mining profits downshifted most in terms of weighted contribution to total profits, though most sectors eased in either growth or absolute terms." But it's very lumpy, very different across different parts of the economy. All these figures are 'quarter on quarter' - from the last quarter of 'September to the end of the December' compared to 'January to March'. Overall: +0.5% Retail: -2.1% Accommodation and food services: -14% But it described the sector data as "very whippy", meaning it moves around a lot. For example, in the three months before, accommodation and food services was +16.7 per cent. The sector-level profit data are very whippy so we wouldn't over-extrapolate the swing, though the details are certainly consistent with policy gaining traction and reducing nominal spending.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's happening in the Australian economy? A mega global bank has a mixed view

children.content: Analysts at J.P. Morgan have given their judgement on our local economy and it's an 'as we expected'.
Essentially, data from businesses supports what the bank thought would happen in the first quarter of this year.
"Mining profits downshifted most in terms of weighted contribution to total profits, though most sectors eased in either growth or absolute terms."

But it's very lumpy, very different across different parts of the economy. All these figures are 'quarter on quarter' - from the last quarter of 'September to the end of the December' compared to 'January to March'.
Overall: +0.5%
Retail: -2.1%
Accommodation and food services: -14%
But it described the sector data as "very whippy", meaning it moves around a lot. For example, in the three months before, accommodation and food services was +16.7 per cent.
The sector-level profit data are very whippy so we wouldn't over-extrapolate the swing, though the details are certainly consistent with policy gaining traction and reducing nominal spending.
